as well as the application is ethical right are there any ways it can be misused is there any part of the data

teams this is a data science template that I often use so I usually start off
with what is the business question that my stakeholders are trying to answer because that way I know that if this is
actually related to a business value or is this a cool fun project that they came up with one day and now they want
someone to work on it what data do you have is there data that already exists or do I have to do a
hunt of data any existing or relevant work related to the project that they are
talking about impact often overlooked but so so crucial especially as a data scientist
it's really important for me to know what is the impact of my work how will the value of the this project be
measured so are there any metrics are there any benchmarks evaluation what is the final
artifact are you looking for a report are you looking for a dashboard are you looking for a model will this be a prototype will this be in
production what is the timeline that's expected and then any additional concept
context around the business problem the analytical problem and the engineering problem so the different phases or
different aspects to the data science project all right so we saw the four

leave you with certain General tips or general advice so what Adventure is
next I've started doing a premortem before a project actually takes place so
it's like a postmortem except it's done before you ask your team to close your eyes and visualize that the project that
you're about about to embark on really important project 6 months down the line is an absolute
failure and then you ask your team to list all the different reasons that could have happened do you not have
access to the data did the executives not believe in your project and ask you to stop working on it did you not get
the right tools did you not have the right discipline what are all those points of failures what are all the
things that can go wrong and once you list them down try to proactively we think of ways that you can reduce the
risk right is there something that you can be proactive about and that you can actively do or maybe there will be a few
things that just aren't in your control but at least having that knowledge is going to be very very empowering and
research studies have done and said that yes right after doing a premortem exercise the morale of the team goes
down but overall in the long run it actually stays higher than without doing
a premortem try to do an assumptions and
questions activity so you list all of the assumptions that you have around the data around your model as well as any
questions that you might have and that again gives you some sort of a starting point right are you making certain
underlying assumptions even within your teams do you have different assumptions from each other so that helps with the
communication and Alignment aspect as well balance between permission and
forgiveness if you can quickly iterate on a small data project that isn't a lot
of time that doesn't take a lot of money go ahead and do it and then ask for forgiveness um otherwise you will just
be stuck waiting for permission right change management really really
important and we're seeing this happen a lot with a lot more AI use cases coming
into our lives people don't trust AI the way they do trust other humans or maybe
other non-intelligent systems um there was this particular case study where a
data scientist was working in the banking industry and um this data scientist was trying to build an an
offer recommendation engine right so as a banking customer you would have the
availability to use certain offers maybe you get a high interest rate or you get uh free monthly you know subscription or
something of that sort and the data scientist went ahead and created a model again looked great on paper great
metrics great accuracy and implemented it into their mobile app
so the users could now use their mobile app which they were anyway using except that they would see these banners pop up
with the recommendations of offers based on what demographic they were you know just a bunch of customer segmentation
done nobody clicked on the offers not a single person this data scientist was
very defeated they then tried to talk to the users and understand that the users actually did not trust the app to give
the right recommendations which is why nobody clicked on those offers the team then worked and changed
things around and instead of giving it directly to the customers or the users these offers were now suggested to the
banking relationship managers those were the people who the users had absolute
trust in and good relationships with so now the relationship manager this Bank
employee could actually see on the screen what offers were recommended for each potential Bank customer or current
user and then they would then advise them and that has a much much higher success rate so again this has to do
with change management make sure you're building trust and credibility in this case the trust didn't lie within the app
but the trust actually was there with the relationship manager from the
